user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_response_entry:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
add_response_entry (struct MHD_Response *response,
                    enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                    const char *header,
                    const char *content)
{
  size_t header_len;
  size_t content_len;

  if (NULL == content)
    return MHD_NO;

  header_len = strlen (header);
  content_len = strlen (content);
  return add_response_entry_n (response, kind, header,
                               header_len, content,
                               content_len) ? MHD_YES : MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function add_response_entry:
static bool
add_response_entry_n (struct MHD_Response *response,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      const char *header,
                      size_t header_len,
                      const char *content,
                      size_t content_len)
{
  if (NULL == response)
    return false;
  if (0 == header_len)
    return false;
  if (0 == content_len)
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\t', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, ' ', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\r', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\n', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\r', content_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\n', content_len))
    return false;

  return MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (response, kind, header, header_len,
                                           content, content_len);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No use of memcmp is present in the provided code fragments. The only memory/string functions used are strlen (to determine header_len and content_len) and memchr (to scan for forbidden characters within the explicitly provided lengths). Neither strlen nor memchr violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (which specifically forbids using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings). add_response_entry_n performs bounds-aware checks using the length arguments and memchr (which operates on a specified length, not on null-terminated semantics), so it is not a Rule 21.14 issue. Note: the call to MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ is outside the provided code; if that function (or other code not shown) uses memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, that implementation would need investigation, but no such use appears in the supplied code fragments.
